trace Module¶

program/module to trace Python program or function execution

Sample use, command line:
trace.py -c -f counts –ignore-dir ‘$prefix’ spam.py eggs trace.py -t –ignore-dir ‘$prefix’ spam.py eggs trace.py –trackcalls spam.py eggs
Sample use, programmatically

import sys

# create a Trace object, telling it what to ignore, and whether to # do tracing or line-counting or both. tracer = trace.Trace(ignoredirs=[sys.prefix, sys.exec_prefix,], trace=0,

count=1)

# run the new command using the given tracer tracer.run(‘main()’) # make a report, placing output in /tmp r = tracer.results() r.write_results(show_missing=True, coverdir=”/tmp”)

class trace.CoverageResults(counts=None, calledfuncs=None, infile=None, callers=None, outfile=None)[source]¶

file_module_function_of(frame)[source]¶
globaltrace_countfuncs(frame, why, arg)[source]¶

Handler for call events.

Adds (filename, modulename, funcname) to the self._calledfuncs dict.

globaltrace_lt(frame, why, arg)[source]¶

Handler for call events.

If the code block being entered is to be ignored, returns `None’, else returns self.localtrace.

globaltrace_trackcallers(frame, why, arg)[source]¶

Handler for call events.

Adds information about who called who to the self._callers dict.

trace.find_executable_linenos(filename)[source]¶

Return dict where keys are line numbers in the line number table.

trace.find_lines(code, strs)[source]¶

Return lineno dict for all code objects reachable from code.

trace.find_lines_from_code(code, strs)[source]¶

Return dict where keys are lines in the line number table.

trace.find_strings(filename)[source]¶

Return a dict of possible docstring positions.

The dict maps line numbers to strings. There is an entry for line that contains only a string or a part of a triple-quoted string.

trace.fullmodname(path)[source]¶

Return a plausible module name for the path.

trace.main(argv=None)[source]¶
trace.modname(path)[source]¶

Return a plausible module name for the patch.
